dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, big news this week from the Supreme Court, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, big news this week from the Supreme Court, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, huge, uh, for Apple, and potentially, like, the entire tech industry.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, huge, uh, for Apple, and potentially, like, the entire tech industry.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The outcome could have implications for any digital retailer, say consumer advocates. It could mean theres going to be a variety of new things the platforms have to consider, says John Bergmayer, an attorney for the consumer advocacy group Public Citizen. That decision could have implications for Google or Amazon. For anyone who runs an app store.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: They actually cleared the way for that antitrust suit against Apple's walled garden approach to the App Store.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They actually cleared the way for that antitrust suit against Apple's walled garden approach to the App Store.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Supreme Court Monday cleared the way for the antitrust suit that centers on Apples walled garden approach to the App store, which has drawn criticism from some companies that use it to deliver services to iPhone users.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. It's that, you know, 30% commission they take, or like, 15% for long-term subscribers, that's really at the heart of it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. It's that, you know, thirty percent commission they take, or like, fifteen percent for long-term subscribers, that's really at the heart of it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Spotify and Netflix have taken issue with the 30% commission that Apple collects from an apps first-year subscriptions and a 15% share of revenue generated from long-term subscribers. That fee also is at the heart of the dispute that rose to the Supreme Court.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And it wasn't even developers suing them directly, was it? It was iPhone owners, which is interesting.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it wasn't even developers suing them directly, was it? It was iPhone owners, which is interesting.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Four iPhone owners filed a suit in 2011, claiming that Apple monopolizes the app aftermarketand extracts a fee that results in higher prices for millions of consumers who use their phones to buy food, arrange transportation or buy movie tickets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, these users from way back in 2011, claiming Apple monopolizes the app market and, um, essentially forces higher prices.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, these users from way back in twenty eleven, claiming Apple monopolizes the app market and, um, essentially forces higher prices.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Four iPhone owners filed a suit in 2011, claiming that Apple monopolizes the app aftermarketand extracts a fee that results in higher prices for millions of consumers who use their phones to buy food, arrange transportation or buy movie tickets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Apple tried to get it tossed out, arguing consumers just lacked legal standing. They even cited this old, like, concrete masonry block case.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Apple tried to get it tossed out, arguing consumers just lacked legal standing. They even cited this old, like, concrete masonry block case.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apple sought to have the suit tossed out, arguing the iPhone owners lacked the legal standing to bring the suit. The tech company cited a decidedly analog precedent, the Illinois Brick case involving pricing of concrete masonry blocks, to argue that consumers can only sue the party that sets the retail price (in this case, the app developers).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] The Illinois Brick case! Yeah, saying consumers can only sue the party that sets the retail price, so, the app developers, not Apple.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The Illinois Brick case! Yeah, saying consumers can only sue the party that sets the retail price, so, the app developers, not Apple.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The tech company cited a decidedly analog precedent, the Illinois Brick case involving pricing of concrete masonry blocks, to argue that consumers can only sue the party that sets the retail price (in this case, the app developers).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But Justice Kavanaugh and the 5-4 majority, they just, uh, weren't buying it. Said Apple's "line-drawing" was "arbitrary and unprincipled."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But Justice Kavanaugh and the five to four majority, they just, uh, weren't buying it. Said Apple's line-drawing was arbitrary and unprincipled.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Justice Brett Kavanaugh, writing for the courts 5-4 majority, rejected Apples arguments, writing that the technology giant sought to draw an arbitrary and unprincipled line among retailers, based upon their arrangements with suppliers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty strong words. Basically, they're saying Apple's trying to gerrymander themselves out of these lawsuits. So, the case continues.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty strong words. Basically, they're saying Apple's trying to gerrymander themselves out of these lawsuits. So, the case continues.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apples line-drawing does not make a lot of sense, other than as a way to gerrymander Apple out of this and similar lawsuits, Kavanaugh wrote. The case will continue through the courts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which is huge, right? For Apple, but also for Google, Amazon, any platform running an app store, really.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is huge, right? For Apple, but also for Google, Amazon, any platform running an app store, really.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That decision could have implications for Google or Amazon. For anyone who runs an app store.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. It could mean, um, platforms have to rethink a lot of things. New considerations for sure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. It could mean, um, platforms have to rethink a lot of things. New considerations for sure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It could mean theres going to be a variety of new things the platforms have to consider, says John Bergmayer, an attorney for the consumer advocacy group Public Citizen.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Apple, of course, is saying they're confident they'll prevail. They claim developers set the price, and most apps are free anyway.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Apple, of course, is saying they're confident they'll prevail. They claim developers set the price, and most apps are free anyway.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Apple issued a statement, saying its confident that it will prevail in court. ... Developers set the price they want to charge for their app and Apple has no role in that. The vast majority of apps on the App Store are free and Apple gets nothing from them, Apple said in a statement.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but you've already seen pushback, right? Like Spotify, who filed that EU complaint, and Netflix, they stopped letting new customers pay through iTunes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but you've already seen pushback, right? Like Spotify, who filed that E U complaint, and Netflix, they stopped letting new customers pay through iTunes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In December, Netflix said it would no longer allow new customers to pay for their monthly subscription fees through iTunes. That follows an earlier move by Spotify, which filed a complaint in March with the European Commission alleging unfair business practices.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Spotify's CEO, Daniel Ek, he really laid it out, saying Apple acts as both "player and referee," stifling innovation.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Spotify's C E O, Daniel Ek, he really laid it out, saying Apple acts as both player and referee, stifling innovation.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In recent years, Apple has introduced rules to the App Store that purposely limit choice and stifle innovation at the expense of the user experienceâ€”essentially acting as both a player and referee to deliberately disadvantage other app developers, wrote Spotify CEO Daniel Ek in a blog post, laying out his grievances.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. And you know how much revenue this brings Apple. The App Store is, like, a huge part of their services income.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. And you know how much revenue this brings Apple. The App Store is, like, a huge part of their services income.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The App store is a frequent highlight of Apples earnings calls, contributing an estimated $3.7 billion of the record $11.5 billion in services revenue the company reported during its most recent quarter, according to market researcher Sensor Tower.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Billions, yeah. So, this isn't just some small thing. This could really change the game for them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Billions, yeah. So, this isn't just some small thing. This could really change the game for them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. It's gonna be fascinating to watch this unfold in the courts.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. It's gonna be fascinating to watch this unfold in the courts.
